reasoning:
Well, I’ve looked at a lot of businesses over the last 60-plus years, and I’m happiest when I stay within my circle of competence. Streaming video strikes me as a complex, fast-changing tech world—lots of competition, huge content costs and razor-thin moats. That’s not Coca-Cola or BNSF, and frankly I’d rather watch from the sidelines.

1. Circle of Competence: I don’t fully grasp the economics of content creation, subscriber churn, and tech platform dynamics. If I don’t understand a business, I don’t invest—simple as that.

2. Moat: Netflix has a strong brand and early mover advantage, but its moat looks more like a trench full of water than an 18-inch concrete wall. Disney+, Amazon Prime, HBO Max and a dozen others are all pouring content in behind it.

3. Management & Capital Allocation: Hastings and company have been bold, but they’ve financed growth with enormous debt and licensing deals. Bold capital spending isn’t always wise allocation when the return is uncertain.

4. Financial Health: Without clear data here on cash flow and debt levels, we can’t say it has the fortress balance sheet we prize—no margin for error if streaming economics weaken.

5. Valuation: There’s no reliable intrinsic value worked out here. In my experience, if you can’t pin down what a business is worth, you shouldn’t be tempted by its price.

6. Long-Term Prospects: Streaming will be around, but the economics are shifting: rising content costs, price sensitivity, global regulation. I don’t see a durable business that will still be winning in 20 years without constant reinvention.

7. Opportunity Cost: I’d rather own a wonderful consumer staples business at a fair price—see’s Candies, Coca-Cola, Apple—than a fair streaming business at any price.

In short, while Netflix is a fine enterprise for some, it sits outside my circle, lacks a clear moat, carries financial risk, and doesn’t offer the margin of safety I demand. I’ll pass for now.
